{{stack begin}} {{taxobox | image = Russula_xerampelina.jpg | image_width = 235px | regnum = [[Fungus|Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | subclassis = [[Agaricomycetidae]] | ordo = [[Russulales]] | familia = [[Russulaceae]] | genus = ''[[Russula]]'' | species = '''''R. xerampelina''''' | binomial = ''Russula xerampelina'' | binomial_authority = ([[Jacob Christian Schaeffer|Schaeff.]]) [[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]] | synonyms = ''Russula erythropoda''
''Russula erythropus'' [[Ernest-René Peltereau|Pelt.]] }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Russula xerampelina'' | whichGills = free | capShape = convex | capShape2 = flat | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter= bare | ecologicalType=mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor=ochre | howEdible=choice }} {{stack end}} '''''Russula xerampelina''''', also [[common name|commonly]] known as the '''crab brittlegill''' or the '''shrimp mushroom''', is a [[basidiomycete]] [[mushroom]] of the brittlegill genus ''[[Russula]]''. Two subspecies are recognised. The [[basidiocarp|fruiting bodies]] appear in [[coniferous forest|coniferous woodlands]] in autumn in northern Europe and North America. Their [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] are coloured various shades of wine-red, purple to green. Mild tasting and [[edible mushroom|edible]], it is one of the most highly regarded brittlegills for the table. It is also notable for smelling of shellfish or crab when fresh. == Taxonomy == ''Russula xerampelina'' was originally described in 1770 as ''Agaricus xerampelina'' from a collection in [[Bavaria]] by the German mycologist [[Jacob Christian Schaeffer]], who noted the colour as ''fusco-purpureus'' or "purple-brown". It was later given its present binomial name by Swedish mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]]. Its [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] is taken from the [[Ancient Greek]] meaning "colour of dried vine leaves", ''xeros'' meaning "dry", and ''ampělinos'' or "of the vine".Giovanni Pacioni1993>{{cite book | author = Giovanni Pacioni | year = 1993 | title = The Macdonald Encyclopedia of Mushrooms and Toadstools (English version) | publisher = Little, Brown & Company Ltd | isbn = 0-316- 90625-5}}{{cite book | author = [[Henry George Liddell|Liddell, Henry George]] and [[Robert Scott (philologist)|Robert Scott]] | year = 1980 | title = [[A Greek-English Lexicon]] (Abridged Edition) | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | location = United Kingdom | isbn =0-19-910207-4}} Two subspecies have been recognised, var. ''xerampelina'' and var. ''tenuicarnosa'', with thinner flesh in the cap and the stipe. The name ''R. erythropoda'' is now considered a [[synonym (biology)|synonym]], and former subspecies ''R.'' (''xerampelina'' subsp.) ''amoenipes'' (originally named by [[Henri Romagnesi]]) now a separate species.{{cite journal | author = Adamcik, Slavomir | year = 2002 | title = Taxonomy of the ''Russula xerampelina'' group. Part 2. Taxonomic and nomenclatural study of ''Russula xerampelina'' and ''R. erythropoda'' | journal = Mycotaxon|volume=82|pages=241–67}} A former variety with a greenish cap, ''R. xerampelina'' var. ''elaeodes'', is now classified as ''R. clavipes''.{{cite journal | author = Adamcik, Slavomir | year = 2004 | title = Studies on ''Russula clavipes'' and related taxa of ''Russula'' section ''Xerampelinae'' with a predominantly olivaceous pileus | journal = Persoonia |volume=18|issue=3|pages=393–409}} As the first defined species, it gives its name to the section ''Xerampelinae'', a group of related species within the genus ''Russula'', occasionally all termed ''R. xerampelina'' in the past. [[Common name]]s include shrimp mushroom, shrimp Russula, crab brittlegill, and shellfish-scented Russula. == Description == [[File:Russ.xeram.jpg|left|thumb|200px|Another colour variation of ''R. xerampelina'']] ''Russula xerampelina'' has a characteristic odour of boiled crustacean. The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is {{convert|6|–|12|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} wide, domed, flat, or with a slightly depressed centre, and sticky. The colour is variable, most commonly purple to wine-red, or greenish, and darker towards the centre of the cap. There are fine grooves up to a centimetre long running perpendicular to the margin. The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] have a mild to rather bitter taste, narrowly spaced, and turn creamy-yellow on ageing specimens. The [[spore print]] is creamy-yellow to ochre. The oval spores measure 8.8–9.9 by 6.7–7.8 [[micrometres|µm]] and are covered with 1 µm spines, The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] {{convert|4|–|8|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.5|–|3|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide, is cylindrical, white or sometimes with a reddish blush, turning ochre or brownish with age. This ''Russula'' has been divided into several similar species by some mycologists. However, they all have the singular dark green colour reaction to iron salts ([[iron(II) sulfate]]) when applied to the flesh, and all smell of shellfish. This aroma is quite distinct, and becomes stronger with age.{{cite book | author = Thomas Laessoe | year = 1998 | title = Mushrooms (flexi bound) | publisher = Dorling Kindersley | isbn = 0-7513-1070-0}} More reddish-capped forms could be confused with the sickener (''[[Russula emetica]]''), although the latter always has a white stipe and gills; greener-capped species may resemble the also edible ''[[Russula aeruginea]]''.{{cite book | author = Nilson S & Persson O | year = 1977 | title = Fungi of Northern Europe 2: Gill-Fungi | publisher = Penguin|isbn=0-14-063006-6|page=122}} == Distribution and habitat == ''Russula xerampelina'' is widely distributed; quite common in northern [[temperate]] zones, and often ranging into the [[Arctic Circle]], it also ranges south to [[Costa Rica]].{{cite web|author=Michael Kuo |date=January 2005 |title=Russula xerampelina |work=Mushroomexpert |url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/russula_xerampelina.html|accessdate=2008-08-26}} Appearing in the autumn, it grows solitary, or in groups with [[conifer]]s,{{cite book |author=David Arora |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms Demystified |publisher=Ten Speed Press |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }} and seems to have a preference for [[Douglas Fir]], or more rarely [[pine trees]] or [[larch]]. It is sometimes found in [[deciduous]] woods, such as [[beech]] and [[oak]]. Variety ''tenuicarnosa'' has been found on sandy soils under pine in Slovakia and northern Italy in [[Trentino]]. == Edibility == The taste of ''Russula xerampelina'' is mild. This ''Russula'' is considered one of the best [[edible mushroom|edible]] species of its genus, although the crab, or shrimp taste and smell will persist even when cooking. This is more pronounced and less pleasant in older specimens.''Mitchell Beazley Publishers ''>{{cite book | author = David Pegler| title = The Mitchell Beazley Pocket Guide to Mushrooms and Toadstools| publisher = Mitchell Beasley | isbn = 0-85533-347-2 | year = 1981}} The young caps are said to be superb stuffed with any suitable ingredients, and are rarely maggoty. == See also == *[[List of Russula species|List of ''Russula'' species]] == References == {{Reflist}} * "Danske storsvampe.
